title: Scientific Notation
kid_friendly_explainer: Scientific notation writes very big or very small numbers in a shorter way: $m \times 10^n$.
The mantissa $m$ must be between 1 and 10 (including 1, but not 10): $1 \le m < 10$.
The exponent $n$ tells you how many places to move the decimal point.
Think of $10^n$ as a decimal point mover: positive $n$ moves right, negative $n$ moves left.

core_rules.name: Standard Form
core_rules.plain_english: Any nonzero number can be written as m × 10^n, where 1 ≤ m < 10 and n is an integer.

core_rules.name: Converting Decimal to Scientific
core_rules.plain_english: Move the decimal point to make m between 1 and 10. Count the moves: left = positive n, right = negative n.

core_rules.name: Converting Scientific to Decimal
core_rules.plain_english: If n > 0, move decimal right n places. If n < 0, move decimal left |n| places. Fill in zeros as needed.

walkthrough: Move the decimal point left to make the mantissa between 1 and 10: \(25{,}000 \to 2.5\).
Count the moves: moved 4 places left.
Move the decimal point right to make the mantissa between 1 and 10: \(0.007 \to 7\).
Count the moves: moved 3 places right.
Move the decimal point in \(4.06\) right 3 places.

easy.directions: Convert between decimal and scientific notation. Remember: $1 \le m < 10$.

items.hint: Move decimal 3 places left to get 5.
Move decimal 3 places right to make 7.
Exponent 2 means move decimal 2 places right.
$10^0 = 1$, so the value stays the same.
Move decimal 1 place right to get 5.
Move decimal 2 places left to get 1.2.

medium.directions: Include negatives and mix directions. Some require back-and-forth conversions and operations.

items.hint: Work with the absolute value first, then add the negative sign back.
Move decimal 3 places right.
Move decimal 4 places right to get 9.2.
Same exponent, so add the mantissas.
Multiply mantissas and add exponents.

challenge.directions: Normalization and mixed operations. Make sure $1 \le m < 10$ in your final answer.

items.hint: Move decimal 5 places right to get 5.0.
Multiply: $9 \times 4 = 36$, exponents: $-2 + 5 = 3$. Then normalize $36 \times 10^3$.
Divide mantissas: $7.2 \div 3 = 2.4$. Subtract exponents: $6 - 2 = 4$.
Rewrite $5 \times 10^3$ as $0.5 \times 10^4$, then add mantissas.
Square mantissa: $2^2 = 4$. Multiply exponent: $3 \times 2 = 6$.

extreme.directions: Trickier alignment and multi-step reasoning. Watch for normalization after each step.

items.hint: Rewrite $4.2 \times 10^4$ as $0.42 \times 10^5$, then add mantissas.
Divide mantissas: $3 \div 6 = 0.5$. Subtract exponents: $-3 - (-7) = 4$. Then normalize.
Multiply: $8 \times 7.5 = 60$. Add exponents: $-2 + 6 = 4$. Then normalize $60 \times 10^4$.
Count carefully: move decimal 10 places right to get 5.6.
Compare exponents first: $10^{-5}$ is smallest, then $10^{-4}$, then $10^{-3}$.

teacher_notes: Emphasize that the mantissa $m$ must satisfy $1 \le m < 10$. Common mistakes include using $m = 25$ or $m = 0.25$.
Remind students that negative exponents are for small decimals (e.g., $0.007 = 7 \times 10^{-3}$), not negative numbers.
When multiplying or dividing in scientific notation: mantissas multiply/divide, exponents add/subtract, then normalize.
For addition/subtraction: exponents must match first, then you can add/subtract the mantissas.
Always preserve the sign of the original number (positive or negative).
